section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to introduce the letters Ss and Tt, sing about animals, and introduce the vocabulary words (travel, journey).
Begin Story Time by asking: Why does mama penguin take a journey to the sea?
Read for enjoyment and understanding.
Check understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Identify at least 20 uppercase and 20 lowercase letters in isolation.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_learning-goal-body: Literacy:Print Concepts; Alphabet Knowledge; Read-Aloud Comprehension

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Teach the lettersSs and Tt.
Read aloud This Is Summer and ToucanCan Talk.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What animal do you see in that book? Where is the animal’s family?
What animal will you pretend to be? What does your family look like?
How many penguins are in baby penguin’s family?
Draw a picture of the penguin family.
What materials can you use to make the penguin family?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word sun? Can you write it?
Can you use blocks to make the penguin family?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Penguin Day by Nic Bishop. Copyright © 2017 Nic Bishop. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder Identify and Solve Problems and introduce vocabulary (adult, communicate)
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to Penguin Day: A Family Story.
Read closely to notice and talk about the Mind Builder.
Offer an extended play opportunity.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Identify and solve problems.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Show motivation to communicate.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children communicate with their peers as they solve a sorting problem.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: Can you find an animal family in the book?
Can you pretend to be Clifford? Can you pretend to solve a problem like Clifford does?
Can you show how you put together a puzzle?
Have you ever had a problem? Can you write about it?
Can you make your favorite animal?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word tiger? Can you write it?
Can you build a tower without letting it fall?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Penguin Day by Nic Bishop. Copyright © 2017 Nic Bishop. Published by Scholastic Inc. Clifford the Big Red DogTM illustration copyright © The Norman Bridwell Trust.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

large-group-materials.tg_materials-caption: Book: Penguin Day: A Family Story

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to build background and teach vocabulary (waddles, keep an eye on)
Begin Story Time by revisiting Penguin Day: A Family Story, and asking the guiding question: What do penguin parents do to feed and protect their babies?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to describe; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Separate syllables from a word.
Identify and solve problems.
Engage with trusted adults and peers to work, communicate, and play.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Engage in movement sequences with adult prompts.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children identify and categorize animal families, noting similar and different features.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: How are baby animals and adult animals the same? How are they different?
Can you show me how penguins walk?
Who is bigger: the baby or the adult? How do you know?
Write about an adult animal and its baby.
How many animal families can you think of? Can you draw and color them?
Find the letter at the beginning of the word sock in the Magnetic Letters. Find the letter at the beginning of the word turtle in the Magnetic Letters.
Can you make the sea that the mama penguins jump into?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Penguin Day by Nic Bishop. Copyright © 2017 Nic Bishop. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

tg_materials-caption.tg_materials-caption_book-title-Ital: Big Chart of Big Ideas: The Chicks Say“Pio, Pio, Pio”

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to talk about animal family units. Introduce vocabulary (chicks, shelter)
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts The Chicks say “Pio, Pio, Pio” and Penguin Day:A Family Story.
Read closely and connect with the concept question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information to compare and contrast; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Distinguish between letters, words, and pictures; Show understanding of left to right and top to bottom directionality in print components.
Show motivation to communicate.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Sing, play musical instruments, and move to the rhythm in classroom activities.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Help children differentiate and connect concepts across two texts.
Invite children to apply Vocabulary Cards to the Big Chart of Big Ideas.
Differentiate and modify as needed.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: What do you think the baby animals want to tell their mama?
Pretend you are a mother hen. How would you show your chicks how to eat corn?
Draw a hen with her wings spread wide. How many chicks can you fit under her wings?
Write about a day with mother hen and her chicks.
Can you create the mother hen and chicks?
Can you draw things that start with the /s/ sound?
Can you build the barn where mother hen and her chicks are?

section-block.tg_copyright-line: TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved. Penguin Day by Nic Bishop. Copyright © 2017 Nic Bishop. Published by Scholastic Inc.
TM ® & © Scholastic Inc. All rights reserved.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Use Circle Time to actively engage children and review vocabulary (journey, communicate).
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking: If you were a mama penguin, what would your journey for food be like?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and enjoyment.
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Share the daily writing option.

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Relate own experiences to those in books; Ask and answer questions about story elements.
Revise and edit group writing; Share and celebrate written products.
Show motivation to communicate.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe the relationship between plants and animals and their environments.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.

section-block.tg_bullet-directions: Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt: Pretend you are baby penguin. Write aboutyour day.
Differentiate and modify as needed.
Save children’s writing to display next week.

section-block.tg_essential-question: How do animals help their babies learn, live, and grow?

section-block.tg_ind-center_teacher-talk: If you wrote your own book about an animal family, what would you put it in?
Can you pretend to be baby penguin? Mama penguin? Papa penguin?
How many people are in your family?
Can you write a story about baby penguin when he grows up?
What materials can you use to make your own family?
Can you find things in your station that start with the /t/ sound?
Can you build a shelter where a penguin family lives? What about a shelter for another animal family?

tg_skills-focus_body.tg_skills-focus-skill-text: Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Name at least 20 uppercase and at least 20 lowercase letters in the language of instruction.
Can distinguish between elements of print including letters, words, and pictures.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environment.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Initiate problem-solving strategies and seek adult help when necessary.
Show competence initiating social interactions.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Observe, investigate, describe and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environment.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Can segment a syllable from a word.
Show initiative in independent situations and persist in attempting to solve problems.
Interact with a variety of playmates and may have preferred friends.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environment.
Coordinate sequence of movements to perform tasks.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Distinguish between elements of print, including letters, words, and pictures
Demonstrate understanding of print directionality, including left to right and top to bottom.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Participate in classroom music activities, including singing, playing musical instruments, and moving to rhythm.
Use information learned from books by describing, relating, categorizing, or comparing and contrasting.
Ask and respond to questions relevant to the text read aloud.
Interact and provide suggestions to revise (add, take out, change order) and edit (conventions) class-made drafts.
Share and celebrate class-made and individual written products.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss the relationship of organisms to their environments.
Create and recreate stories, moods, or experiences through dramatic representations.
